metadata.title: Materials, Structures, and Functions for Flexible and Stretchable Biomimetic Sensors

sections.heading: Materials, Structures, and Functions for Flexible and Stretchable Biomimetic Sensors
sections.text:
Published as part of the Accounts of Chemical Research special issue “Wearable Bioelectronics: Chemistry, Materials, Devices, and Systems”.
Tie Li, Yue Li, and Ting Zhang*
i-Lab and Key Laboratory of Multifunctional Nanomaterials and Smart Systems, Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics (SINANO), Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), 398 Ruoshui Road, Suzhou 215123, P. R. China
CONSPECTUS: Currently, flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensing electronics have obtained a great deal of attention in various areas, such as human−machine interfaces, robotic smart skins, health care monitoring, and biointegrated devices. In contrast with the traditional rigid and fragile silicon-based electronics, flexible and stretchable sensing electronics can efficiently capture high-quality signals when integrated on curved surfaces due to their elastic and conformal characters, which are expected to play many important roles in the foreseeable age of intelligence. Its realization strongly relies on rapid advances in the development of high-performance and versatile flexible and stretchable sensors, and effective ways to achieve high performance are rational designs of the sensing materials and microstructural configurations. This Account showcases the recent progress in flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors covering several critical aspects of materials, structures, and applications. Nature-inspired active matter and architectures, which have been well-tuned by evolution through millions of years of optimization, provide us the best learning choices to overcome the restrictions of current sensor techniques such as low sensitivity, instability, and delayed response time. Biomimetic sensing materials and microstructural patterns can efficiently acquire synthetic response abilities, endowing the new-type flexible sensors considered as “smart” electronic components on account of the counterparts to living organisms. Moreover, the developments of diverse functions and multifunctional applications become more and more important in the creation of novel flexible electronics beyond those existing technologies. For instance, flexible and stretchable sensors with the capability of mimicking various human behavioral patterns can be developed to boost the emergence of artificial robots, which can take the place of human beings in strenuous activities, enabling progress in social science, technology, and productivity to improve the quality of human life. For the above purpose, inspired by the in-depth understanding of working principles of living organisms how to operate their natural characteristics, sensing materials with stimuli response (light, humidity, mechanics, etc.) and multifunctionalities (superhydrophobicity, degradation, self-healing, etc.) provide distinctive and multiple detection features generally encountered in their traditional counterparts. In addition, artificial micro- to nanostructures derived from naturally existing high sensitivity structures (such as insect crack or leaves) and stretchable configurations (wrinkle, texture, mesostructures, etc.) offer additional feasible strategies for producing favorable sensitivity and stretchability. Flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors with analogous senses to those of human beings (such as tactile and auditory senses) have attracted tremendous attention for their diverse applications for next generation smart electronics. The long-term progress of these novel sensors influencing the next generations of bioinspired intelligence systems and medical electronics are also envisioned.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Currently, flexible and stretchable electronics have become the most exciting frontier for the next generation of electronic devices, which can conform to soft and curved shapes.1 In the future, they are expected to play much greater roles in the foreseeable age of intelligence and make great changes to our daily life. One of the effective ways to achieve the objectives is the design of highly sensitive and diverse flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors. To meet the special characters and requirements, rational design and fabrication of diverse
sensing materials and novel structures are essential. Various strategies for materials and structure design have been developed in past tens of years. For example, the emerging nanostructured materials like carbon nanotubes and graphene have been selected as attractive candidates for combination with designed micropatterned stretchable substrates to fabricate sensors that are flexible, stretchable, or both.2
Received: September 30, 2018
Article

As the most distinguished concept of flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors, “Electronic skin (E-skin)” represents the functional sensing imitation of the human skin, endowing superb characteristics such as superhydrophilicity, biocompatibility, biodegradability, and renewability beyond the restrictions of existing rigid materials and structures and their functions. Benefitting from analogous working principles of living organisms, such as photonic crystals in butterflies providing structural color, the hierarchical microstructure on the lotus leaf supplying low water adhesion and superhydrophobic properties, and a tunable elastic modulus in skin affording excellent mechanical flexibility and robustness, the flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors can meet the requirements of broadening applications of electronic devices, making them employable in diverse fields such as artificial robots, prosthetics, and implanted health monitoring.3 For example, flexible biomimetic tactile sensors could help the artificial robot “smartly feel” real-world objects through finger touching and body motions. In this Account, to showcase a summary of recent research advances toward flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors, we present on this topic containing classes of sensing materials, microstructural architectures, and device applications covering several critical aspects of flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensor technology.

sections.heading: 2. SENSING MATERIALS
sections.text: To acquire flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors with diverse synthetic properties except mechanical sensitivity, one of the most important strategies is to exploit novel sensing materials aiming at the externally stimuli-responsive features and inherently physicochemical essences of living organisms. Here, multiparameter and multifunctional sensing materials were reviewed as the developing direction of flexible materials.

sections.heading: 2.1. External-Stimuli-Responsive Materials
sections.text:
Multiparameter responsive capacity for various external stimuli is well-established in natural creatures and endows living beings with adaptive capacity to their surrounding environment for survival. For example, sensory receptors in skin respond to physical stimuli including mechanoreception, thermoreception, and nociception. The operation principle of
the biological response to external stimuli is a smart organization of sensory, nervous, and locomotor systems that correspond to integrated functions, such as the input, transmission, and processing of information, as well as actuation.4 Inspired by these special properties, novel materials with responsive behavior upon exposure to multiparameter stimulus are developed to fabricate new types of flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors.6−9 These are generally considered as “smart” electronic components on account of the correspondence to living organisms. Typically, the responsiveness of diverse sensing materials to ambient stimuli through desired shape deformation, including magnetic elastomers, light-activated sodium alginate−MoS2, and hygroscopic polymers, endows flexible sensors with the similar abilities as those found in natural creatures interacting with external survival conditions.5 For example, a light and humidity dual response film has been realized to bend quickly through the adsorption and loss of bound water (Figure 1a).6 Especially, these stimuli-responsive materials afford the unique opportunity to build fully soft smart robots for mimicking the complex motions of soft animals without a linked power supply. For instance, a soft robot with thermal response can execute soft bodied crawling to mimic an inchworm through coupling environmental sensing of the sensors with a corresponding response of the actuators (Figure 1b).7
Besides the above features, the combined function of mechanical stimuli induced self-driven behavior is also a special but ubiquitous capacity existing in nature, which can convert outside stimuli into sensing signals. Self-powered sensors exhibit favorable potentials in fabricating self-driven flexible smart electronics due to the strain-induced voltage and current. We prepared a piezoelectric sensor based on c-BN nanocrystals, revealing a recordable piezoelectric coefficient of 25.7 pC/N.8 In addition, we investigated vertical piezoelectricity of the CdS nanosheet at atomic scale by in situ scanning Kelvin force microscopy, showing a vertical piezoelectric coefficient up to 33 pm·V−1, which is much larger than that of the bulk. It may pave the way to positioning an object with extreme precision.9 These findings shed light on the design of next-generation smart devices with dual functions of mechanical sensing and self-driven behavior.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00497 Acc. Chem. Res. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
B

sections.heading: 2.2. Inherently Multifunctional Materials
sections.text:
As the concept of E-skin means the functional imitation of human skin, currently, multifunctionalities have become an attractive tendency of flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors, which can combine mechanical sensitivity with other inherent essences of biological surfaces of living organisms, such as biocompatibility, superhydrophobicity, biodegradability, and renewability, besides the above-mentioned external stimuli response ability.10
Biocompatibility is a crucial consideration for assembling flexible biomimetic sensors when they are closely attached to or implanted in biological surfaces. A feasible strategy to achieve biocompatible devices is to employ naturally occurring materials. For example, silk is a natural protein without unknown biotoxicity and is suitable to fabricate biocompatible and strong adhesive epidermal electronics.11 Meanwhile, the developments of tissue friendly bioelectronics also need biodegradable materials to avoid invasive removal surgery. For instance, a moisture-driven physically transient sensor system can entirely degrade within well-controlled times without the redundant processing of resorption solutions (Figure 2a).12
Superhydrophobic surfaces can efficiently protect the flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors in various environments through reducing the adhesion of dust particles and water, which is an efficient water-proof and self-cleaning property
existing in nature such as the wings of insects, plumage, and lotus leaves. Here, we prepared a multifunctional superhydrophobic smart coating film with carbon nanotubes and thermoplastic elastomer (MWCNT/TPE) composite. It can be directly sprayed on any substrate like clothing to form flexible and stretchable sensors for real-time detection of mechanical forces under extreme alkali and acid conditions (Figure 2b).13 Other materials like TiO2 were also synthesized and used as superhydrophobic coatings.14
Further, since damage is unavoidable when attaching on the biological surface, self-healing ability is very valuable for the long-term stability of the sensors. Among them, hydrogels are one of the ideal candidate materials for their abundant hydrogen-bond based reversible cross-links. For example, acryloyl-6-aminocaproic acid permanently possesses a selective self-healing function responding to different pH conditions under an aqueous environment (Figure 2c).15 However, it remains a challenging task to combine properties of pressure sensitivity and self-healing in one man-made material. A stretchable film prepared by integration of graphene and polymers was described to mimic both the pressure sensitivity and mechanical self-healing character of natural skin, showing the lowest detection range as low as 0.02 kPa even under stretching or bending conditions.16
Moreover, due to the highly conductive and elastically mechanical properties, soft materials also provide the acute
DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00497 Acc. Chem. Res. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
C
potential to construct stretchable sensors to adapt to the stretchability of biological surfaces in organism tissues. The typical example is ionic conductors which are composed of a special structural modality of gels swollen with ionic liquids, showing a solid form with stretchable and transparent features similar to animal soft tissues. A serial of artificial devices derived from ionic conductors was introduced to operate the same as the tissues covering the heart with high frequency stretchability.17 Also, ionic conductors were employed to fabricate a stretchable electroluminescent device just like the color changing of octopus with extreme stretching strains up to 700%.18

sections.heading: 3. MICRO- AND NANOSTRUCTURES
sections.text: Besides developing novel materials, another feasible strategy for producing high-performance biomimetic sensors while achieving high sensitivity and stretchability is to construct flexible and stretchable structures accommodating large strain and geometrical deformations such as bending, twisting, folding, and stretching.19 Here, the development in novel artificial micro- and nanostructures from the views of naturally existing configurations is introduced.

sections.heading: 3.1. Highly Sensitive Structures
sections.text:
Since many natural organisms can achieve high-performance sensing ability by controlling their physiological structures, nature-inspired artificial architectures have been utilized for the development of highly sensitive flexible biomimetic sensors. For instance, the spider, a swift insect, can use its crack-shaped
slit organs near the leg joints to sense infinitesimal mechanical stress variations. According to this phenomenon, a flexible sensor based on nanoscale crack junctions was demonstrated and obtained ultrahigh sensitivity to strain and vibration.20 We also assembled a flexible sensor by transferring the as-patterned graphene on flexible polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) substrate with high crystallinity carbon electrode, which reveals asymmetric tensile-compressive response through compression and separation of crack carbon junctions, same as the spider’s slit geometry (Figure 3a), showing great reproducibility to monitor vibrations from a phone timer.21 Moreover, naturally existing architectures of micro- or nanovesicles with similar crack structure also provide potential strategies to develop distinctive sensing materials.1−3,19
Additionally, the micro- and nanostructures existing in natural plants can be also employed as effective soft molds to acquire micropatterned flexible substrates to assemble highly sensitive sensors. For example, a flexible capacitive tactile sensor was prepared by our group based on the combination of the double dielectric layers of polystyrene microsphere/air with the micropatterned flexible PDMS substrate duplicated from lotus leaves (Figure 3b), which shows optimum performance of sensitivity (0.815 kPa−1) with a large response range (0.2−50 N) and a short response time (∼38 ms).22 Also, the mimosa petal was used as nano-in-microtemplates to enhance the properties of flexible pressure sensors.23
DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00497 Acc. Chem. Res. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
D
3.2. Stretchable Configurations
Mechanical mismatching between biomimetic sensors and flexible biological surfaces usually interferes with the sensing properties. A feasible strategy to overcome this problem is to develop mechanically compatible and superplastic sensors.24 Instabilities, such as human skin texture, gastrointestinal wrinkles, and sand dunes, commonly exist in natural environments, which are analogous to superplastic architecture that can disappear and reappear or stretch and recover under an outside force. The fabrication of artificial biomimetic instabilities has been investigated to fabricate complex patterns to assemble stretchable electronic devices. The most popular strategies of superelasticity mainly contain three modes of “wrinkle structure”, “wavy configuration”, and “stretchable interconnects”, and these methods are often reciprocally used.25−35 Here, the architectural strategies for flexible and stretchable sensors are summarized from the view of structural
configurations of fiber, plane, and blocks depending upon the morphological modes. So far, the prestrain strategy is usually adopted to achieve artificial wrinkle instabilities like one-dimensional (1D) sheath−core structure. It arose from the heterogeneous stress distribution existing in the interior of composite materials, leading to self-organized micro- and nanopatterning substrates. These features can make physically flexible and stretchable properties of devices deviate substantially from their bulk counterparts.25 We reported a sheath−core fiber-based ultrastretchable sensor with enormous strain enhancement over 1135% (Figure 3c) and high stability (20 000 cycles load/ unload test), which can monitor drastic human motions from the large-scale deformation of elbow or knee joints, such as squatting, extending, and jumping.26 Also, twisted and helical structures were introduced to assemble flexible and stretchable sensors by employing the nature’s gyroscopic principle.27
DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00497 Acc. Chem. Res. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
E
Additionally, emerging tactics in achieving highly integrated flexible and stretchable fiber-like sensors with self-powered capacity have also been demonstrated as promising wearable functional devices. For example, owing to an advanced built-in twisted structure, a stretchable sheath−core triboelectric fiber was developed to serve as a self-powered multifunctional kinematic sensor, exhibiting an ultrahigh working strain (100%) and high response sensitivity (17.4 per unit strain) to compressing, stretching, and bending.28
Further, uniform large-area 2D wrinkle patterning can be obtained through controlling the conformal contact between the material and substrate during strain relief. Other important approaches, including island−bridge layout and serpentine shape connections, are also employed usually to bond inorganic semiconductors to prestrained elastomer substrates to form flexible and stretchable sensors. Rarely, artificial products are used to provide rich surface textures in microscale to form the wavy-like structure. For example, we have found high-quality silk textiles with microstructured surface intertextures can offer a simple and effective soft mold to uniformly fabricate large-area patterned PDMS substrates (Figure 3d), which can lead to flexible pressure sensors with superior sensitivity (1.80 kPa−1) and high stability (>67 500 cycles).29
The limitations of sensing materials with 1D and 2D structures are more or less caused by interface problems like percolation and sliding, such as unstable electrical conductivity and poor reliability arising from the discontinuity of the conductive network. To overcome these restrictions, selfassembled three-dimensional (3D) block configuration is a practical option to assemble lightweight flexible sensors for stretchable and recoverable compression network interconnectiions. For example, reliable all-carbon conductive foams with joint-welded cross-link structure showed highly stable resistance and elasticity under both tensile and compressive deformations, demonstrating attractive merits to prepare flexible and stretchable sensors.30 In addition, metal nanowires like silver31 and copper32 are also popular flexible sensory materials, as well as the inherently stretchable organic conductors.33 Moreover, foams composed of elastomers usually are sensitive to environmental variations such as temperature and moisture; hence it is highly desirable to produce self-compensated sensors for direct and precise detection.34
Importantly, it is worth mentioning that the brand-new stretchable interconnects demonstrated by J. A. Rogers and coauthors have attractive possibilities for application in flexible sensors via controlling formation of 3D filamentary mesostructures, which are transformed from compressive 2D geometric micro- and nanostructures. They have demonstrated more than 40 representative geometries with various level configurations by theoretical and experimental research.35

sections.heading: 4. DEVICE FUNCTIONS
sections.text: Based on the recent progress in sensing materials and sensor structures, novel device functions and various applications of flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors can be realized.

sections.heading: 4.1. Biomimetic Sense Functions
sections.text:
Improved understanding of basic sense functions of living organisms, such as pselaphesia, auditory sense, smell, and optesthesia, provides possibilities for the creation of novel flexible electronics that employ analogous engineering mechanisms and operational characteristics beyond those
existing technologies. As the largest organ of the living body, the skin has its prominent pselaphesia capacities to perceive minor changes of pressure and tension. Artificial E-skin is able to imitate or even improve the partial features of skin through integrating various sensing materials with flexible or stretchable substrates. For pressure sense, we developed a flexible E-skin sensor by combining two layers of patterned carbon nanotube−PDMS composite films, which demonstrate ultrahigh sensitivity for pressure detection with fast response time (<10 ms) and low detection limit (0.6 Pa). Benefitting from its high sensitivity, the E-skin attached around the radial artery of the wrist can distinguish the tiny difference of pulse pressure between persons with various body conditions (Figure 4a).29 Furthermore, a novel flexible bandage-like system integrating E-skin with a wireless transmitter was demonstrated to measure weak jugular venous pulse (JVP) waveforms of arterial tonometry or pulses in the neck epidermis, which has a close relation to the clinical diagnostics of heart failure risk like arrhythmias and pericardial disease.36
Meanwhile, tactile sense is able to recognize surface textures through shear force. It is an intriguing challenge to make E-skin capable of detecting the shear force.37 We designed a novel flexible sensor called an “electronic fingerprint” inspired by the epidermal−dermal and outer microstructures of the fingerprint, which shows improved ability of haptic perception and surface texture recognition (Figure 4b) with high pressure sensitivity (3.26 kPa−1 in a wide range of 0−300 Pa). The device can discern the minimum dimension of microstripe as small as 15 μm × 15 μm (interval × width) and was employed to discern the braille alphabet, inverted pyramid patterns, and different silk patterns.25,38
To endow flexible biomimetic sensors with auditory sense to “hear” sound, through optimizing the micropattern, weight, and strain state of the flexible mechanosensor, a kind of ultrathin flexible sensor called a flexible “electronic eardrum” was fabricated to detect sound signals (Figure 4c), which can sense and record vibration signals in a wide frequency domain of 20−13000 Hz with high signal-to-noise ratio (∼55 dB) and durability (150000 cycles).39 Further, to achieve the functional integration of producing and inspecting sound in a single device, an artificially biomimetic throat was developed with controllable ability of sound-sensing and converting.40 These characteristics may provide opportunities for implantable acoustical bioelectronics in clinical prosthetics applications. Other sense of feeling functions also can be realized through constructing the corresponding flexible biomimetic sensors. For instance, an electronic nose, a technical device usually connected with flexible gas sensors, is demonstrated to mimic the olfactory function of discriminating smell.41 Similarly, a biomimetic visual imaging technique has attracted interest. In particular, some insects have compound eyes with high sensitivity to infrared or ultraviolet, besides visible, spectrum.42 Moreover, a 3D printed e-tongue was prepared and applied to soil analysis that was enriched with several macronutrients to plants (N, P, K, and Ca).43

sections.heading: 4.2. Multifunctional Applications
sections.text:
In the future, flexible electronics, composed of mechanically flexible biomimetic sensors like E-skin, will be developed to detect and quantify various stimuli to imitate the sensorium systems of living bodies with the multifunctional sensations of tactile sensing, temperature, and humidity. Recently, a skininspired highly conformable and flexible sensor array was
DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00497 Acc. Chem. Res. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
F
successfully assembled to expand the sensing multifunctionalities, including but not limited to pressure, temperature, inplane strain, humidity, light, and even magnetic field (Figure 5a).44 Similarly, a fingertip skin-inspired microstructured sensor was demonstrated to discriminate multiple spatial tactile stimuli containing vibration, temperature, and static and dynamic pressure.36
Additionally, various physical signals produced from human activities, such as body/joint motions and muscle movement, can generate a series of strain or stress change, which are also important health indicators. Our results show that a multifunctional mechanical sensor can be fabricated by directly spraying a superhydrophobic smart coating on various flexible structures to detect different kinds of force like strain and torsion, which can be employed for full-range and real-time detection of human motions (Figure 5b).13 We also prepared a buckled fiber-based stretchable sensor to realize multifunctional applications of monitoring body muscle motions and evaluating tendon injury rehabilitation (Figure 5c).26
Moreover, noninvasive continuous monitoring of body fluids has important significance toward the assessment of body health information. For example, a wearable sweatband sensor platform can provide abundant insight into the user’s health state through the detection of sweat biomarkers such as ions, lactic acid, cortisol, etc.45 Similarly, skin humidity caused by sweat is also one of the most common factors to assess the
comfort of the living environment. We assembled a flexible humidity sensor for multifunctional application as a noncontact switch system and an attachable smart label, respectively, showing that the switch responded favorably to RH change of a finger approaching and the label assessed humidity changes of a person’s facial skin at different measuring time (Figure 5d).10 Moreover, we designed and fabricated a flexible noncontact sensor array through assembling reduced graphene oxide films, which can also sense humidity variation when a finger approaches, demonstrating potential multifunction in human−machine interaction.46
Besides the above-mentioned signals, some animals also have specific multifunctional natural response to external conditions. Among them, the smart skin on chameleons or cephalopods has the unique characteristic to adjust their color. This significant capability is expected to prompt development of flexible biomimetic sensors to mimic such a function for bionic robots. For example, a deformation-controlled surfaceengineering method was developed to assemble multifunctional sensors that can realize four mechanochromic roles via strain-dependent cracks and folds inspired from these display tactics.47 In particular, the integration of various flexible sensors with other techniques is also a way to realize multifunctionality. For instance, an artificial afferent nerve constructed by integrating pressure sensors and ring oscillators
DOI: 10.1021/acs.accounts.8b00497 Acc. Chem. Res. XXXX, XXX, XXX−XXX
G
with synaptic transistor provides feasible solutions to detect the complex physiological signals, inherently neurological signals, which can obtain the underlying mechanism of biophysiological activity. The results can be used to assemble hybrid bioelectronics to drive muscles, ultimately realizing the biomimetic function of the human nerve response to a movement behavior.48

sections.heading: 5. SUMMARY AND OUTLOOK
sections.text:
In this Account, we have summarized recent progress in flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors from the views of sensing materials, micro- and nanostructures, and diverse applications. In the future, there may be two important directions for the development of the flexible biomimetic sensors. The first involves the development of customizable “smart’” materials from the views of molecular design to realize high sensing performances. For example, shape-memory metamaterials, metal−organic frameworks, and supramolecular polymers with programmable element constitutions, crystal forms, and energy bands are attractive and instructive for the construction of multifunctional sensing materials. Also, other unconventional functional materials like molecular-machine ligands, “green” beneficial bacteria, and tailorable matters can be potentially employed to fabricate stimuli-responsive devices, which possess the ability to respond to environmental stimuli through conformational variations of molecular structures and further offer feedback to macroscopic observation. Second, multifunction-oriented integration through rational engineering of structural design will become an important topic for biomimetic electronic systems, not only for the enhancement of mechanical tolerance but also for integrated and “smart” responses. For example, different from the present mutually independent devices, the conceptually multifunctional and integrated design is the most important consideration in the whole bioinspired system like bionic fish swimming in the water, bionic birds flying in the sky, and even bionic reptiles moving in the earth. In addition, a better development of the interplay between bionic device design and multifunctional systems may determine a path to a brighter future of realizing artificial intelligence systems. In a word, it is hoped that this Account provides stimulating highlights of this interdisciplinary research frontier.
■ AUTHOR INFORMATION Corresponding Author
*E-mail: tzhang2009@sinano.ac.cn.

sections.text: The authors declare no competing financial interest.

sections.heading: Biographies
sections.text:
Tie Li received his Ph.D. degree from Fudan University, China, in 2014, and then he joined Professor Ting Zhang’s group as a
Postdoctor since 2014−2017. Currently, he has become an Associate Professor at Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He has published more than 20 papers, and his research interests include flexible sensors for wearable electronics and programmable materials for energy conversion.
Yue Li received her B.S. degree in applied chemistry from Sun Yat-sen University, China, in 2017. She is currently pursuing a M.S. degree in physical chemistry at Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and NanoBionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Her current research focuses on materials innovation and structure design toward soft electronics.
Ting Zhang is a Professor leading a research group at Suzhou Institute of Nano-Tech and Nano-Bionics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He received his Ph.D. degree in chemical engineering at University of California, Riverside, in 2007. His research mainly focuses on combining high-throughput and manufacturable printing and MEMS techniques for the fabrication of electronic nanosensors and individually addressable nanosensor arrays. He has published more than 50 papers and applied for more than 25 Chinese patents (12 were authorized) and 2 international patents.

references.title: A Bioinspired Flexible Organic Artificial Afferent Nerve
author: Folds. Nat

metadata.abstractText: CONSPECTUS: Currently, flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensing electronics have obtained a great deal of attention in various areas, such as human−machine interfaces, robotic smart skins, health care monitoring, and biointegrated devices. In contrast with the traditional rigid and fragile silicon-based electronics, flexible and stretchable sensing electronics can efficiently capture high-quality signals when integrated on curved surfaces due to their elastic and conformal characters, which are expected to play many important roles in the foreseeable age of intelligence. Its realization strongly relies on rapid advances in the development of high-performance and versatile flexible and stretchable sensors, and effective ways to achieve high performance are rational designs of the sensing materials and microstructural configurations. This Account showcases the recent progress in flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors covering several critical aspects of materials, structures, and applications. Nature-inspired active matter and architectures, which have been well-tuned by evolution through millions of years of optimization, provide us the best learning choices to overcome the restrictions of current sensor techniques such as low sensitivity, instability, and delayed response time. Biomimetic sensing materials and microstructural patterns can efficiently acquire synthetic response abilities, endowing the new-type flexible sensors considered as “smart” electronic components on account of the counterparts to living organisms. Moreover, the developments of diverse functions and multifunctional applications become more and more important in the creation of novel flexible electronics beyond those existing technologies. For instance, flexible and stretchable sensors with the capability of mimicking various human behavioral patterns can be developed to boost the emergence of artificial robots, which can take the place of human beings in strenuous activities, enabling progress in social science, technology, and productivity to improve the quality of human life. For the above purpose, inspired by the in-depth understanding of working principles of living organisms how to operate their natural characteristics, sensing materials with stimuli response (light, humidity, mechanics, etc.) and multifunctionalities (superhydrophobicity, degradation, self-healing, etc.) provide distinctive and multiple detection features generally encountered in their traditional counterparts. In addition, artificial microto nanostructures derived from naturally existing high sensitivity structures (such as insect crack or leaves) and stretchable configurations (wrinkle, texture, mesostructures, etc.) offer additional feasible strategies for producing favorable sensitivity and stretchability. Flexible and stretchable biomimetic sensors with analogous senses to those of human beings (such as tactile and auditory senses) have attracted tremendous attention for their diverse applications for next generation smart electronics. The long-term progress of these novel sensors influencing the next generations of bioinspired intelligence systems and medical electronics are also envisioned.
